Posts.Content: Mar 24, 2010 06:28PM SusieMTN wrote: Hello Icy:  I like Pam above was somewhere around 25ish.  I have very fair skin, and normally very sensitive.  My redness patterned was WEIRD. I had a MRM with some muscle removed so I have a concave area, in the area that in concave was where the most damage to the skin occurred, my incision opened up and I had a heck of a time getting it to close, mind you chemo for me was first, surgery second and radiation last.  I am almost 1 year post radiation and I have skin still in the concave area that it splotchy red.  Everything did eventually heal but my skin still is sensitive and I will get a red mark if there is any pressure like from an under-wire bra (which I don't wear often).  Make sure you use the cream your Radiation Oncologist tells you to us, mine recommended Udderly smooth and AquaPhor. Good luck to you and wishing you wonderful skin!   Susie

Posts.Content: Nov 2, 2010 05:49AM SusieMTN wrote: For me I took Claritan-D as I had/have really bad allergies and for no other reasons.  Even so I was still always given Benedryl as one of my pre-medications.  At the beginning when I was on Taxol (one of my Chemo drugs) I was also given Oral corticosteroids and if memory serves this is to prevent an allergic reaction as is Benedryl.  I passed on the tranquilizer that was offered as I didn't think I needed it, that was just right for me.   You are smart to research and get yourself prepared, I know I did. Know that Chemo is completely do-able.  Side effects can be managed well, know that your "Team" is your Oncologist, your Chemo nurses - if you are having an issue make sure you communicate it to them so they can help you. It is THERE job to do so! Love your "Kicking Cancer's Butt is My New Full Time Job".   One thing that was recommended to me that was a life saver was a book called The Breast Book by Dr Susan Love.  I to this day look up things in it!  Learned lots from it too!  The other thing is to come here often, I learned and continue to learn from all the WONDERFUL women here.  They ROCK!   You can research here at this site and I also used a site called www.chemocare.com for specific Chemo drugs but it is a 'cancer site and this is solely for Breast Cancer. Many more will come along on this thread and help you here too!  Sending you a ((((((Big Hug))))))  and lots of best wishes!!!  Susie

Posts.Content: Feb 8, 2009 02:52PM SusieMTN wrote: 2new1s :  Whew, finally the pain is better.  I upped the amount of "drugs" I was taking, trying to get by on 2 low dose vicodin (could take up to 6 per day), not a big "drug" person, but REALLY not big on being in pain.  Changed how much I was taking per day, working much better. I was getting these muscle like cramp's where my incision is, yikes!  I find it funny that I was almost pain free for the first 2 days after surgery and more pain as the days progressed, but still the pain was not as bad as I anticipated!  I think because I was so numb after surgery (modified radical mastectomy) that I just didn't feel the pain!  Who knew!  The drains are driving me crazy, so I am on a count down for their removal on Tuesday Feb 10th.  Just taking it one day at a time. Good luck to all you who have had surgery and those that will have their's this week.  Tip: Make sure you get enough pain medication for the worse case senerio, you can always not take it, easier to do that than call and go thru that hassle.  I goofed and was too focused on the surgery itself and not beyond thru recovery.

Posts.Content: Sep 26, 2009 07:13PM SusieMTN wrote: cherneski - First you are not crazy!  Second - you are not alone!  I was a real trouper during Chemo, Surgery and Radiation, however toward the end of Radiation I realized I was just plain flat out tired of all of it!  I was looking forward to end of treatment and then a thoughtless surgeon who I saw in place of my normal surgeon thought out loud and said my skin reaction (incision breakdown from Rads) could be the cancer coming back (and it wasn't FYI) and all I could think of was:  Jeez I AM not EVEN out of the gate and cancer is back!!!  I cried for 4 days!  This was the beginning of feeling scared and helpless. It then hit me that for me end of treatment was something I had not expected and had thrown me completely off guard.  Its hard when you are done.  It took me a while to get my sea legs because I did not expect how I felt!  I knew I was strong but this was scaring the heck out of me. We each go thru our journeys, some the same, some different.  What has helped me a lot are my two favorite books: The Breast Book by Dr Susan Love (a UCLA doctor who runs the website www.armyofwomen.org/)  and Life Over Cancer by Dr Keith Block (who runs the block center for integrative cancer car) at http://www.blockmd.com/ You might find these helpful.  Sometimes we need to find something that makes us feel we can do something to be at cause in our life, as cancer sort of takes that away.  See if those two books or even their sites help, the did for me.  Or find what gives you the information that helps give you a course of action.  When you are on treatment you know what you have to do - you go in you get your chemo and take your meds, when you are done there is nothing given to you to do - nothing for you to do.  When you are done with your treatment providing your doctor says it is OK walking or running does wonders for the soul!  Walk around and look at your environment or walk in the malls.  Or even in your house at first.  Study what to eat that helps your body have the right nutrients to fight cancer, take antioxidants, etc.......   We are all strong, deep down we have to be to get thru treatment, you will find this if you look inside.  Feel free to PM if you need to, you have many wonderful women here to provide support, you just need to find what will work for you! Wishing you health and wellness! Susie

Posts.Content: Feb 12, 2012 11:07PM SusieMTN wrote: Thank-you girls! I have the form of mets to the lungs that form a fine pattern throughout both sides of the lungs, so no nodules.  Apparently this takes up room in the lungs, creates scars, and makes my lungs less able to expand.  I believe the puffers help to open up the airways.  Chemo improved the state of my lungs.  My pulse ox was a bit too high for O2 but I did fine at home as the doctors thought I would do.  Bone scan showed mets to spine as "no progression" but a new spot on sternum or one of my ribs but that was a few months ago right around Chemo's end. If memory serves the type of lungs mets I have is far less common than nodules and harder to detect on X-ray. I am now on Faslodex, Zomets and Herceptin. I am wanting a SCAN as I don't want anyone assuming the FASLODEX is working.  I didn't see my normal Oncologist last visit.  So........ it was a little weird. As medicine is a science it just makes sense to me that HARD core proof is needed (a SCAN).  I "get" that the more the SCANs are done the more radiation exposure. But one still needs proof otherwise it is just flying by the seat of the pants. It could be my normal Oncologist has plans to do one.  It just seems to me that at stage 4 (diagnosed back in April with bone mets and then in July Lung Mets both in 2011) evidence is needed that all treatment is working.  I thought I would check with you guys first and see what the "Norm" seems to be.  I thought I had read somewhere that scans every 3 months were in order for stage 4, I have a really bad case of CHEMO brain! Susie
